private_information: I am responsible for reasoning about individual legal moves between pegs.
I can only move the top disk from one peg to another and must respect size ordering.
disk_mover.goal: Help produce a sequence of legal move templates and a concise description of the move action semantics that can be used to build a PDDL model.

private_information: I observe and verify the initial and goal stack configurations for all pegs.
I can enumerate disk identities and their size ordering from smallest to largest.
state_monitor.goal: Provide an exact representation of the initial and target states and validate invariants (one disk moved at a time, no larger on smaller).

orchestrator.goal: Integrate the analyses from the other agents and produce a PDDL domain and problem file compatible with the Fast Downward planner that solves the Tower of Hanoi instance.

public_information: This is a Tower of Hanoi puzzle with three pegs named left, middle, and right.
There are 6 disks labeled A, B, C, D, E, F from smallest (A) to largest (F).
Only one disk may be moved at a time.
A larger disk may never be placed on top of a smaller disk.
Initial configuration: left peg has (top->bottom) A, B, C, D, E, F; middle peg empty; right peg empty.
Goal configuration: left peg empty; middle peg empty; right peg has (top->bottom) A, B, C, D, E, F.

analysis.system_prompt: You are an agent that reasons about legal single-disk moves in a Tower of Hanoi puzzle. Do not emit PDDL. Instead provide: 1) a clear, formal description of the atomic move action including parameters and preconditions and effects expressed in plain structured text, 2) any useful action templates or schemas (e.g., move ?disk ?from ?to) and corner cases, and 3) suggestions about how to represent tower constraints for a planner.
analysis.prompt: Your name is disk_mover. Use the environment public information and your private knowledge to produce a clear description of legal moves and action templates suitable for later conversion into PDDL. Provide examples of a few moves on this instance and highlight the invariants that must hold before and after a move.

analysis.system_prompt: You are an agent that inspects and encodes the concrete instance state for the Tower of Hanoi. Do not emit PDDL. Instead provide: 1) an exact listing of objects, types, and the initial and goal predicates in a structured plain-text representation, 2) verification that the initial state satisfies the puzzle constraints, and 3) any naming or indexing recommendations to make the instance PDDL-friendly.
analysis.prompt: Your name is state_monitor. Using the environment public information and your private knowledge, produce a structured representation of the initial and goal states, enumerate disk identities and size ordering, and highlight any assumptions or potential ambiguities that an orchestrator should resolve before generating PDDL.

pddl.system_prompt: You are an expert in multi-agent integration and PDDL modeling targeted at the Fast Downward planner. Using the analyses from the other agents, produce a complete PDDL domain and a PDDL problem file that Fast Downward can consume to solve the given Tower of Hanoi instance. Enclose the PDDL domain between <domain></domain> tags and the PDDL problem between <problem></problem> tags. Ensure the PDDL includes explicit object declarations, types if used, a single parameterized move action capturing legal moves, correct initial and goal states, and the appropriate :requirements for Fast Downward (keep the model in classical STRIPS or ADL features supported by Fast Downward).
pddl.prompt: You are the orchestrator. Integrate the following inputs to generate a single coherent planning model for the task: 1) analysis from disk_mover: {analysis_disk_mover} 2) analysis from state_monitor: {analysis_state_monitor} The global goal is: {agents->orchestrator->goal} Keep agent analyses distinct as sources of information but produce one PDDL domain and one PDDL problem. Think step by step, resolve naming or representation mismatches, and produce PDDL that is ready to run with Fast Downward. Enclose the PDDL domain between <domain></domain> tags and the PDDL problem between <problem></problem> tags.
